full_conversation: Therapist: Welcome, Aisha. How are you feeling about today's session?
Client: I'm... I'm not sure. A bit anxious, I guess. We're going to talk about the cyberbullying, right?
Therapist: Yes. Are you ready to begin?
Client: I think so. It's just... it's hard to go back there, you know?
Therapist: I understand. Remember, you're safe here. Let's start with a SUDS rating.
Client: Um, maybe a 6? My heart's already racing a bit.
Therapist: Okay. Take a deep breath. Now, close your eyes and describe the first incident.

Client: (Takes a deep breath) Okay... I'm in my dorm room. It's late, maybe 11 PM. I'm scrolling through Instagram, and suddenly I see it. A photo of me from a party last weekend, but... it's been edited. They've... they've made me look... fat. Grotesque. The caption says, "This is what happens when you let a cow loose at a party."
Therapist: Stay with that moment. What are you feeling?
Client: I... I feel sick. My stomach's in knots. I can't believe someone would do this. I thought these people were my friends. I'm... I'm shaking.
Therapist: Good. Keep going. What happens next?

Client: I... I start reading the comments. They're all laughing. Calling me names. "Fatty," "Elephant," "Go back to your country, you don't belong here." I... I can't breathe. It feels like the walls are closing in.
Therapist: Remember, you're safe here. Take a slow, deep breath.
Client: (Inhales shakily) I... I want to defend myself, but I'm scared. If I say anything, they might make it worse. I feel so alone.
Therapist: What's your SUDS level now?
Client: It's... it's an 8. Maybe even a 9. I feel like I'm right back there.
Therapist: You're doing well. Stay with it. What do you do next?

Client: I... I shut off my phone. I can't look anymore. But I can't stop thinking about it. What if everyone sees it? What if my parents find out? I... I start crying. I can't stop. I feel so helpless.
Therapist: Focus on those feelings. Describe them.
Client: It's like... like there's this heavy weight on my chest. I can't breathe properly. My face is hot with shame. I feel... I feel worthless. Like maybe they're right. Maybe I don't belong here.
Therapist: Stay present. What's happening in your body?
Client: My hands are shaking. I... I feel nauseous. I want to throw up. I curl up on my bed, hugging my knees to my chest. I can't stop crying.
Therapist: Good. You're doing great. What's your SUDS now?
Client: It's... it's still high. Maybe an 8.
Therapist: Okay. Take another deep breath. What happens the next day?

Client: I... I don't want to go to class. I'm terrified of facing everyone. But I force myself to go. As soon as I walk into the lecture hall, I hear whispers. People are looking at me, laughing behind their hands. I... I feel so exposed. Like everyone knows.
Therapist: How does that make you feel?
Client: Humiliated. Angry. I want to disappear. I sit in the back, trying to make myself as small as possible. I can't focus on the lecture. All I can think about is that photo, those comments.
Therapist: Stay with those emotions. What else?
Client: I... I start to doubt myself. Maybe I am too fat. Maybe I don't fit in. I... I skip lunch. I can't bear the thought of eating in front of others. What if they're watching me, judging me?
Therapist: Remember, you're safe now. How's your SUDS?
Client: It's... it's coming down a bit. Maybe a 7 now.
Therapist: Good. Keep going. What happens next?
Client: I... I go back to my room after classes. I check my phone. There are more comments. Someone's created a meme with my photo. It's... it's everywhere now. I feel like I can't escape it.
Therapist: How do you cope with that?
Client: I... I don't know how to cope. I feel so overwhelmed. I... I think about hurting myself. Just to make the pain stop. But I'm scared to do that. Instead, I... I call my mom.
Therapist: That's a positive step. What happens when you call her?

Client: I... I break down as soon as I hear her voice. I tell her everything. She's worried, angry on my behalf. She wants to call the school, but I beg her not to. I'm afraid it'll make things worse.
Therapist: How does talking to your mom make you feel?
Client: It... it helps a little. I don't feel so alone. But I'm still scared. I don't know how to face everyone tomorrow.
Therapist: What's your SUDS level now?
Client: It's... it's down to a 6, I think.
Therapist: Good. You're doing well. What happens in the following days?

Client: It... it gets a little better. Some friends reach out, tell me they've reported the post. It gets taken down eventually. But... but the damage is done. I still feel anxious every time I go online. I'm always waiting for the next attack.
Therapist: How do you handle that anxiety?
Client: I... I start avoiding social media. I change my privacy settings. I'm careful about what I post. But it's hard. I feel like I've lost a part of my life. I miss feeling carefree online.
Therapist: That's understandable. How are you feeling now?
Client: It's... it's not as raw anymore. But I still feel vulnerable. Like it could happen again at any moment.
Therapist: Your SUDS?
Client: Maybe... maybe a 5 now.
Therapist: You've done very well. Let's take a moment to ground ourselves.
Client: Okay... (takes a deep breath) I... I didn't realize how much it still affected me.
Therapist: It's normal. You've shown great strength today.
Client: Thank you. I... I feel drained, but also... maybe a little stronger?
Therapist: That's good. We'll end here for today. How are you feeling?
Client: Tired, but... okay. I think I'm at a 4 now.
Therapist: Excellent. We'll discuss coping strategies next time.
Client: Okay. Thank you, Dr. Thompson. This... this helped.
Therapist: You're welcome, Aisha. Take care of yourself this week.
